Review Title: Uncrowded, but fewer animals than its neighbour yala
Review Text: Peaceful and uncrowded park.  We were the only jeep in sight for most of the trip. Usual animals: elephants, deer, crocodiles, buffalo, many types of birds.  No leopards.  A more relaxed experience, good if you don’t need a constant parade of wildlife

Outstanding trip. Best ever. Roads are more even than Yala. Best of all we saw two leopards. Had a really good look at them. Also saw two hornbills quite clearly. Several elephants coming quite near. Spotted dear. Birds of prey, painted stalks, bee eaters. Harsha was our guide and he was knowledgeable and patient.
untouched and less commercial than the others. can see elephants in thier natural habitats. beautiful secenaries.

We went on the safari organized by our hotel (Tranquil Wild) and it was absolutely great experience. We heard stories about overcrowded Yala National Park, where hundreds jeeps packed with tourists try to spot elephants and leopards... We wanted to have it an easy way and we got what we wanted - hundreds of birds, peacocks, several elephants, crocodiles, turtle, eagles...no leopards but we were still really happy! There was only one jeep beside us. Perfect morning. Go there!

We set out at 5am for this trip but it was perfect. Just us in our jeep with a very good careful driver and a friendly and knowledgeable guide. it was peaceful and unhurried. We were in the park for approx 4 hours and only saw one other jeep. We saw a huge array of beautiful animals and birds waking up in the wild with no stress of even being aware of us being there.

We visited this park in the afternoon having been to Yala in the morning, and far preferred it.   It was much less busy, and unlike Yala when we did see elephants, jackals etc we had them to ourselves rather than a scrum with scores of other jeeps arriving. Very enjoyable visit.

So here is some information about this park. Very limited on information. Lucky we found some locals at Priyanthanee Hotel where we stayed. I don’t know local language but I can just say the things I had seen. First off, didn’t see any jeeps out front. This place is not commercialized at all. Actually we were the only ones in the whole park, on Sunday. We seen so many animals though. Wow. Incredible time today in the wildlife safria of Tanamalwila, Sir Lanka. Seen today about 100 birds, monkeys of course, elephants, deer, crocs, lizards, many peacocks, foxes and so much more. Will make a video on it soon so stay in touch on my YouTube. Epic! Forest Destine So if coming here I highly recommend finding a hotel to help you or take your time coming here. You might have to question things all day long even before you can find a Jeep, driver and even a ranger as a guide. But we seen so much. It was truly an amazing experience.

Lunugamvehera National Park lies between Yala and Uda Walawe national parks. 184 species of bird have been recorded in the park, mostly forest birds and water birds.Sri Lankan junglefowl, Sri Lanka woodstrike, painted stork, Brahmin kite, grey hornbill and many kinds of Eagles can be seen at the park. It is a home to elephants, spotted and sambar deer, wild buffalo, giant squirrel, palm cat, sloth bear and leopards.

We did an afternoon safari entering at Ruhunu. There are a lot of birds to be seen,  such as Asian Open Bill, Hoopoo and Hornbill, and if you are lucky as we were, you may spot a leopard. Varied and beautiful countryside. No crowds.
It is very good national park.  And it is a new park for safari at Yale jungle.  There no many jeeps.  Only 5 or 6 jeeps are entering to the park every day.  Lots of animals with leopards and birds.

Nice park with lots of animals to see. We weren’t lucky enough to see a leopard but we had some pretty good jackal encounters, 2 species of monkeys and more than 50 bird species. Our driver was very good. He drove slowly and carefully and stopped immediately when told by the park guide or us. His name is Walter, company name: Sellam Safari. mobile: 0702000097/98 The Jeep (fitting 6 people) was Rs 8000 for the whole group (4 hours turned into 5 hours). Entry fee into the park was US$ 10 (+ 8US$ service fee per group, + 15% tax).

This is the ideal place to visit if you are looking for a peaceful and less crowded national park for safari. Lunugamwehera also known as the block 5 of Yala national park has many scenic locations around the Weheragala Reservoir. We saw many birds and animals during our visit and highly recommend a safari here as you can experience wild life without any disturbances.

We saw: Redback jackels Yellow-wattled lapwings Red-wattled lapwing Changeable hawks Serpent hawks Malabar Pied hornbills Peahens and peacocks Western purple faced langurs Common hoopoe Black-rumped firebacker Painted storks Open bill stork Elephants Green bee eaters Blue-tailed bee eater Bulbul Munia Spotted deer Water buffaloes Crocodiles Grey mongoose Green pigeon It rained for part of our safari which I found very refreshing. Of course we had to put our cameras away for a while. After the rain we continued on. I got some really great shots of the wildlife, especially the birds!! Loved this place.

My wife and I spent the whole day here during our recent Birdwatching Tour of Sri Lanka 🇱🇰. As others have said, much quieter than Yala and apart from Leopards 🐆, everything is easier to see and at a much more leisurely pace. Stunning array of bird life. We particularly enjoyed watching the Little Swift fly below us as we stood on the Dam. Lots of Asian Elephant 🐘 and Water Buffalo 🐃 (Feral) Spotted Deer 🦌 (Chital) were abundant as were Toque Macaque and and Tufted Grey Langur. We even managed to find a single Indian (Black-naped) Hare and the only Golden Jackal of the trip. A thoroughly enjoyable visit. Highly Recommended.

Lunugamwehera National Park is a paradise. No more jeeps, very relaxing place to visit. Lots of birds to see. Elephants crocodiles and leopards also. Beautifully lakes ant two big water reservations. Many type of eagles.

Very nice park with plenty of animals. Unlike yala this park is not crowded. Also the people who visit the PARK and the trekkers are more disciplined. We were fortunate to see many elephants. Two of which came charging at us. The veheragala dam adds to the beauty of the park.
Lovely park indeed. Beautful scenery by the reservoir. Good place for some photo shoots. Saw plenty of sea eagles.
The safari is quite lengthy but found it enjoyable. we were really fortunate to see two Leopards! That's after a long ride around the park. but it really paid it off!

Went here this morning and we saw lots of birds .. one elephant .. stripe necked mongoose, spotted deer but no leopard! The leopard seems to be the gold star spotting that every one wants to get to see. But I really enjoyed the less busy safari and the forest itself is of such great beauty .. well worth the visit. Next time maybe we ll see the elusive leopard ❤️

We rated this National Park much higher than Yala its neighbour National Park which is more popular and therefore much more busy. We had a truly magic day there. Millions and I mean millions of lemon butterflies decided to hatch the day we were there and it felt like being in an enchanted forest.  The vegetation was lush and we had so many opportunities to see wildlife as there are much fewer safari jeeps visiting.  We were very lucky and saw a pair of leopards which made our day!

We recently visited Sri Lanka to do a number of Safaris.  This little known National Park had beautiful scenery, a variety of animals - yes we even saw a leopard chasing a spotted deer and best of all we only came across one other safari jeep.  If you have the time, this National Park is certainly worth a visit, even if just for the serenity of being in such a beautiful place.We were able to take a number of great shots up close, except for the leopard as they move like lightening.

We had a good trip with no other tourusts but regretted not going at dawn. Started at 10h and it quickly got hot. Saw some great birds and stunning scenery with wallowing wuld buffalos, jackals and deer but no chance of a leopard. We paid lkr 6000 to go in and lkr7000 for the jeep.

Lunuhamvehera National Park or Block 5 of Yala National Park also known locally ad Yala Jadhika Udyanaya is a vast national park. Despite the 4 hours safari the number of animal sightings are sporadic with some crocodiles, peacocks, other birds, water buffaloes, spotted deers and some small monkeys. Rather uncomfortable jeep ride due to the rough trails. Hefty price for the safari and the entrance fees. No where compared to any African Wild Life Safaris. However if you are in Tissamaharama town for want of a better thing to do go for it but keep your expectations low and you may be surprised.

A good Park with lesser number of visitors. The park is a lesser sized park compared to other National parks. we visited in September and we found animals were less, probably due to the fact that the season was very dry and hot without rain for the past few months. Animals are very rare during the daytime and were not roaming around much. Peacocks and Deer were very very common all around the park. Various types of Birds like Eagles and few small birds were found. The Bungalow we spent the Night was situated in a very beautiful location overlooking a lake but due to the Weather it was partly dry but was the home for a number of Crocs. A good place to spend the night feeling the breeze coming from the Park. Cook is available and you can provide materials to cook for meals. Electricity and Water is available

This park is smaller than Yala which is shut for parts of the year, and therefore a bit more rustic and quieter. Lots of birds due to the abundant water and small number of elephants and water buffalo. Oh, did I forget to mention the leopard .  What a magnificent animal.  So lucky to view one of only a dozen in the park.

Getting away from the crowd in Yala's main feature (block 1) we got to Lunugamvehera National Park. Actually also Yala but this is block 3! No traffic jams and here we did see leopards! Please do note that the drivers here are exclusively focused to find the prized leopard. Although it's wonderful to find them but it did give me the feeling nothing else matters.

This park is one of the least visited parks as most people visit the famous Yala block 1. As a result this park is almost empty and ideal for bird, leopard, elephant, deer, bear sightings. I highly recommend a full day safari where the jeep cost will be Rs. 10,000. Make sure you book a Toyota Hilux cab or Mitsubishi L200 cab and never a Mahindra jeep because the Mahindra is uncomfortable and engine makes a loud noise scaring away animals. Also, check if your safari jeep front glass can be opened to give you a better view. If you visit this park make sure you go to Lunugamwehera and book from there and never from Yalal because safari jeeps in Yala take you to Yala block 5 claiming that it is Lunugamwehera where it is not!! It is only a part of Lunugamwehera which is also called block 5.

Compare national parks in other counties such as in the USA, Kenya and in South America, this is a small park, but even in low season when I am visiting, there are still way too many visitors in too many safari jeep,,

This is a total contrast to the the busy safari park at Yala, where the jeep drivers had no respect for the animals and were only interested in getting as close to the animal as possible, crashing into each other and frightening the leopard away so no one got to observe it. But in the lesser known Lunugamvehera, which we entered opposite Block 3 entrance to Yala, it was tranquil and peaceful as not many people use it. We spotted an abundance of wildlife, and we saw 3 leopards on our afternoon safari. In contrast to the terrible behaviour of safari jeep drivers at Yala, here the drivers were respectful of the animals and were content to sit quietly and observe the leopards. Would definitely recommend over Yala any day, which is much busier.
This area is absolutely stunning. The scenery, trees and wildlife incredible. We saw 3 leopards in 1 day. We won't forget this any time soon.

Lunugamvehera is one of the lesser known National Parks of Sri Lanka. It is not too popular with tourists, as a result of which the park is not overcrowded. The park is in the catchment area of the Lunugamvehera reservoir. The park contains Elelphants, leopards, deer and a wide variety of birds. The dead trees standing in the reservoir's water was a very scenic sight. I was lucky to sight a leopard late in the evening along with jackals, mongooses, deer and birds like Brown Fish-eagle, Crested Hawk-Eagle, Hornbills, Pied Kingfishers etc. Lunugamvehera is worth a day visit!

Visited during August and it was very dry and dusty. Came out covered with dust and saw less elephants as they have all gone into dense jungle. But got the opportunity to eye some wild boars, lots of deer, birds, alligators, peacocks. Also had the rare sight of alligator hunting down a bird...Weheragala reservoir inside is very nice and refreshing place. There are lots of fish and can even get down and go closer and have a good foot massage. Landscape is really nice and varying...but wet season would be the best to visit as many jeeps were inside as Yala was closed. And visit in early morning which will give you more beautiful scenery.

Yala has lots of animals but loads of tourists and queues. If a leopard is sighted it is bedlam. This was much more authentic. Less numbers of animals but they all seemed more active and we got to get into the forest on small trails. We had close encounters with 2 leopards and with elephants. We saw crocodiles in action and eagles and other birds as well as herds of deer. A great afternoon.

If you are a wildlife photography lover like me, this is a must visit place. From elephants to birds to deers to caymans you'll get to see all these animals in one place. We went through the new gate which was opened to public on 17th December 2016. And we were the first lot to drive through one of their newly opened track. New gate is just 30 to 40 mins drive from Thissamaharama town. You have to take A2 highway towards lunugamvehera town and Turn Right to Lunugamvehera reservoir at L'vehera town. Drive all the way to the end till you reach the park entrance and ticket office. You will at least need a good 5 to 6hrs to roam around the entire park. More time the better. 6am to 6pm is the park open time. I suggest you go early in the morning or around 3pm in the arvo.

We saw lots of elephants, deer, rabbits, crocodiles, beautiful birds and reservoir has a beautiful scenery. We entered through the newly opened gate  from lunugamvehera reservoir side so animals are not very familiar with vehicles so fan away as we reach . Very friendly staff .

This is declared as Yala block IV. This park is not reechoed as Yala. This park is have nice landscape and there are lot of spotted deers are rooming around the park. There are possibility to site leopard as well.

We had a grate safari trip in Lunugamvehera \\\yesterday afternoon.  i accompanied with My SRI  directors . We could see, Elephants,Lepored , Shamber, Spoted Deer, crocodile,  and more birds. this is beautiful park, no more jeeps, We used yala eco safari   jeep. Mr. Teddy was a driver.

I visited Yala the DAY before it opened, so had no option but to visit block 5, Lunugamwehara national park. It's like the poor cousin of Yala, however the same entrance fees (Rs. 3,708.07) applies. This is before you pay the safari operator +Rs.5,000 per person. An expensive day out. Wonderful natural smell and surroundings, although everything was so dry and dusty. Spotted 2 leopards briefly before a car park of Indian safari vehicles arrived along with their diesel exhaust. Saw lots of spotted deer, peacocks, monkeys, eagles, crocodiles, monitors, but sadly no elephants.

It’s September which means the annual closure of Yala National Park due to the  drought and maintenance. 2nd week of September with the long weekend I decided to head down to Yala and visit nearby wetlands and an alternative national park. we went to the park around 6 .00 am morning.there were only few jeeps at the entrance. no traffic was there like yala. we able to spot excellent birding , three leopards, two sloth bears and herds of spotted deers. we had only half day safari. but this is good for full day as well.

We wanted to visit Yala National Park, but found out after booking the trip that this park is closed 1 Sept-15 Oct each year.  Disappointed we decided to visit Lunugamvehera National Park.  $100 for a driver, jeep and guide for 3-4 hours driving around the park.  We didn't see much and there were quite a few other jeeps because Yala was closed.  Saw a few elephants (3), 1 King Mongoose, lots of birds, spotted deer, barking deer, and a mouse deer.  Better than not going but do not expect much.  Leopards were no where to be found.

I visited Lunugamvehera for the first time, couple of weeks back. This is the Yala Block 5 and the best thing was there were only us and another Jeep. The park is not crowded. Afternoon visits are recommended since there is a chance of seeing a leopard. Must have a good 4x4 and an experienced tracker.

This time, on my way to Yala National Park, I decided to cross the Lunugamvehera National Park. I have entered to the park from Kalupaalama Entrance, Thanamalvila with a special permission. Soon after entering, you can have a river bath in Kirindi Oya river. Then you can proceed to Galge exit point which will take you to Buttala-Kataragama road. It is actually great experience to cross this jungle with your own vehicle. You can observe large groups of Spotted deer, Buffaloes and Sambur. You can have a rest on Weheragala Dam and that place is really beautiful place to be. Also you can hire a safari jeep for a tour as well. if you use your own vehicle, it should be 4x4 and should have high ground clearance.

Our guide suggested this Park due to the closure of Yala National Park for a month in September. We were so looking forward to a full day safari at Yala National Park therefore we were obviously disappointed in the closure but we went to Lunugamvehera National Park with a heavy heart. We took the afternoon trip and was greeted by both an elephant and monkeys just at the entrance of the park which perked up our day. During the next 3 hours we saw lots of black faced monkeys ( whose scientific name I've forgotten ), many peacocks and peahens, spotted dears, iguanas, many species of birds including the pelicans, toucans, kingfishers, stocks, parakeets, white bald eagles, water buffaloes but just 2 elephants. We also visited the Lunugamvehera Reservoir. Overall it was a good safari , many thanks to our wonderful guide Sri Sanjeevan and our driver Rohan. We find the Park average mainly because in Malaysia, we too have many of the animals spotted in the park. Yala and its leopards would be better but then again maybe I'm biased. Thanks again to Sri and Rohan.

I know lot of people are interested in going to Yala and the place is some what crowded. Two weeks back I was there with a person from the area. I saw at least 50 deers in one go and around 500 during the tour inside the park. We saw plenty of elephants as well. This area is adjoining the Yala block 5 which most of the tourist are not being taken to and the animals of the Yala stage 5 move into this area pretty often. As per the experience of the local person he has spotted 2 leopards during another visit and that was during evening. But during my visit I did not sight any leopards. This area has a lovely view of greenery compared to Yala.

Lunugamvehera National Park is one of the major national park in Sri Lanka which situated and bordered to Yala National Park. You can visit this National Park via two (02) main routes as follows: Via Colombo>Rathnapura>Uda walawe>Thanamalwila to Lunugamvehera (approximately 231km) Via Colombo>Hambantota>tissamaharama>thanamalwila to Lunugamvehera (approximately 265km) By visiting here you could observe Wild Elephant, Wild Boar, Leopard, Wild Buffalo, Crocodiles, Spotted Deer, Rabbits, Peacock and variety of Birds. It has Three bungalows inside the National Park which you could book via Department of Wild Life-Sri Lanka. Following link will provide additional details regarding the bungalows. http://www.dwc.gov.lk/library/Bungalows.html
